title: Psi font
content:
This is the symbol Psi

I am wondering if anyone knows what fonts will have this as a part of their character set?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141012212049im_/http:/typophile.com/files/psych_symbol_6475.jpg)
author: Chris Dean

comments.content:
Hi Christopher,

it depends:  
psi is a Greek character ( [U03A8](http://web.archive.org/web/20141012212049/http:/www.decodeunicode.org/u+03A8) for uppercase), so it is included in _every_ font with Greek language support.

Then, it could be used as a symbol in mathematical typesetting. There are a couple of codepoints, depending on its application: [U1D7A7](http://web.archive.org/web/20141012212049/http:/www.decodeunicode.org/de/u+1d7a7), [U1D6BF](http://web.archive.org/web/20141012212049/http:/www.decodeunicode.org/de/u+1d6bf), [U167A7](http://web.archive.org/web/20141012212049/http:/www.decodeunicode.org/de/u+1d7a7), [U1D76D](http://web.archive.org/web/20141012212049/http:/www.decodeunicode.org/de/u+1d76d), [U1D733](http://web.archive.org/web/20141012212049/http:/www.decodeunicode.org/de/u+1d733), [U1D6F9](http://web.archive.org/web/20141012212049/http:/www.decodeunicode.org/de/u+1d6f9).

Special fonts like Cambria Math will likely contain these glyphs.  
F
Can you recommend actual font names? I don't quite understand your response.

Oh, I’m sorry I confused you with numbers.  
Basically, I wanted to ask you whether you’re typesetting Greek text, or if you just need the ‘Ψ’, e.g. for a mathematical application.  
If the latter is true, then what is your basic typeface? Regarding style/weight, it better should be a close match, no?
It is for a poster. I would like to have as many Psi characters on it as possible.

Ah, okay!

Here are a [couple of fonts with Greek language support](http://web.archive.org/web/20141012212049/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=greek) distributed by FontShop (check out ‘Character Set’ to view the ‘Ψ’), and some more by [Linotype](http://web.archive.org/web/20141012212049/http:/www.linotype.com/en/86463/keyword/greek.html) (» ‘Encoding map’).  
I couldn’t figure out how to filter Greek fonts at MyFonts.com in a reasonable way.

Luc Devroye maintains a [List of Greek fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20141012212049/http:/cg.scs.carleton.ca/~luc/greek.html).
